title: Assertion `col >= 0 && col < line->cols' failed, process aborted while streaming ouput from remote server
vulnerability_information:
**Summary:**
During the course of testing putty-0.70-2019-03-01.e0a7697 on Fedora 29 compiled with clang version 7.0.1 (Fedora 7.0.1-4.fc29), we discovered it was possible to abort a remote client by streaming data at it in such a way as to trigger an assertion failure in terminal.c.

```
putty: terminal.c:259: void clear_cc(termline *, int): Assertion `col >= 0 && col < line->cols' failed.
Aborted (core dumped)
```

**Description:** 
An assertion is a statement that a predicate (Boolean-valued function, i.e. a true–false expression) is always true at that point in code execution. It can help a programmer read the code, help a compiler compile it, or help the program detect its own defects. 

In this case, we can trigger the PuTTY client, using escape codes streamed from a remote connection, to resize itself in such a way as to trigger this Assertion Failure which aborts the client. 

## Steps To Reproduce:
1. Download https://tartarus.org/~simon/putty-snapshots/putty.tar.gz
2. Extract putty.tar.gz
3. change to the putty directory created in step 2.
3. `CC=clang CXX=clang++ ./configure && make -j5`
4. Launch PuTTY with your favorite debugger.
5. Connect to a remote host of your choice
6. On remote host: mkdir corpus && git clone https://gitlab.com/akihe/radamsa.git && cd radamsa && make && sudo make install && cd ~
7. On remote host, upload the attached JPG file to the corpus directory we created in step 4. 
8. On remote host type while true; radamsa -s 911 -o - -n inf corpus/*; done and let run until crashes.

## Supporting Material/References:
I've uploaded the core dump that happened at the time of the crash.

## Impact

Denial of service, crash, loss of data contained in scroll back
vulnerability_information_html:
Summary:
During the course of testing putty-0.70-2019-03-01.e0a7697 on Fedora 29 compiled with clang version 7.0.1 (Fedora 7.0.1-4.fc29), we discovered it was possible to abort a remote client by streaming data at it in such a way as to trigger an assertion failure in terminal.c.

putty: terminal.c:259: void clear_cc(termline *, int): Assertion `col >= 0 && col < line->cols' failed.
Aborted (core dumped)

Description:
An assertion is a statement that a predicate (Boolean-valued function, i.e. a true–false expression) is always true at that point in code execution. It can help a programmer read the code, help a compiler compile it, or help the program detect its own defects.

In this case, we can trigger the PuTTY client, using escape codes streamed from a remote connection, to resize itself in such a way as to trigger this Assertion Failure which aborts the client.

Steps To Reproduce:

  1. Download https://tartarus.org/~simon/putty-snapshots/putty.tar.gz
  2. Extract putty.tar.gz
  3. change to the putty directory created in step 2.
  4. CC=clang CXX=clang++ ./configure && make -j5
  5. Launch PuTTY with your favorite debugger.
  6. Connect to a remote host of your choice
  7. On remote host: mkdir corpus && git clone https://gitlab.com/akihe/radamsa.git && cd radamsa && make && sudo make install && cd ~
  8. On remote host, upload the attached JPG file to the corpus directory we created in step 4.
  9. On remote host type while true; radamsa -s 911 -o - -n inf corpus/*; done and let run until crashes.

Supporting Material/References:

I've uploaded the core dump that happened at the time of the crash.

Impact

Denial of service, crash, loss of data contained in scroll back

activities.message: I left out formatting on #9 above, it should be `while true; radamsa -s 911 -o - -n inf corpus/*; done`.
activities.markdown_message: I left out formatting on #9 above, it should be while true; radamsa -s 911 -o - -n inf corpus/*; done.

activities.message:
Managed to catch a backtrace with gdb:
```
#0  0x00007ffff6f4553f in raise () at /lib64/libc.so.6
#1  0x00007ffff6f2f895 in abort () at /lib64/libc.so.6
#2  0x00007ffff6f2f769 in _nl_load_domain.cold.0 () at /lib64/libc.so.6
#3  0x00007ffff6f3d9f6 in .annobin_assert.c_end () at /lib64/libc.so.6
#4  0x000000000047684c in clear_cc (line=<optimized out>, col=<optimized out>) at terminal.c:259
#5  0x000000000047684c in copy_termchar (destline=<optimized out>, x=<optimized out>, src=<optimized out>) at terminal.c:317
#6  0x000000000047684c in term_display_graphic_char (term=0x783a00, c=<optimized out>) at terminal.c:2779
#7  0x000000000046fd2b in term_out (term=0x783a00) at terminal.c:3279
#8  0x0000000000473197 in term_added_data (term=0x783a00) at terminal.c:6719
#9  0x0000000000473197 in term_data (term=0x783a00, is_stderr=<optimized out>, data=<optimized out>, len=<optimized out>) at terminal.c:6727
#10 0x000000000043f747 in chan_send (ch=0x2, err=160, buf=0x0, len=140737336595775) at ./sshchan.h:73
#11 0x000000000043f747 in ssh2_connection_filter_queue (s=0x5a91d0) at ssh2connection.c:534
#12 0x000000000043f06a in ssh2_connection_process_queue (ppl=0x5a9280) at ssh2connection.c:948
#13 0x000000000040caf5 in run_toplevel_callbacks () at callback.c:121
#14 0x000000000047c0c6 in idle_toplevel_callback_func (data=0x2) at unix/gtkcomm.c:208
#15 0x00007ffff714897b in  () at /lib64/libglib-2.0.so.0
#16 0x00007ffff714c06d in g_main_context_dispatch () at /lib64/libglib-2.0.so.0
#17 0x00007ffff714c438 in  () at /lib64/libglib-2.0.so.0
#18 0x00007ffff714c762 in g_main_loop_run () at /lib64/libglib-2.0.so.0
#19 0x00007ffff794bb6d in gtk_main () at /lib64/libgtk-3.so.0
#20 0x0000000000489601 in main (argc=<optimized out>, argv=<optimized out>) at unix/gtkmain.c:667
```

activities.message:
Hello @geeknik,

Your time and effort in submitting this report are much appreciated, I am now in contact with the internal team and will get back to you as soon as there's an update.

Regards,
@nasr0x01

activities.message:
Hello @geeknik,

Thank you for your submission! I was able to validate your report, and have submitted it to the appropriate remediation team for review. They will let us know the final ruling on this report, and when/if a fix will be implemented. Please note that the status and severity are subject to change.

However, in future reports, could you please include the actual test case that caused the crash? that would help us triage your reports faster.

Regards,
@nasr0x01

activities.message: Curiosity prompts me to ask what makes this one less severe than say #495508? Thanks!
activities.markdown_message: Curiosity prompts me to ask what makes this one less severe than say #495508? Thanks!

activities.message:
Hello @geeknik,

Thanks for the follow-up, the severity is set to Low on this one as opposed to #495508 because in #495508 it can be triggered by a single application on the server, to deny service to all the other applications running on the server and it doesn't seem the case for this bug.

I hope this makes sense.

Regards,
@nasr0x01

activities.message:
Hello @geeknik,

Thank you for this report. The team have confirmed your vulnerability as a Low severity impact.

The H1 platform doesn’t allow €URO payments, hence the funky $283.83 amount.

The USD$ conversion for today is 1 United States Dollar equals 0.88 Euro.

Thanks for your help and participating in this program.

Kind Regards
HackerOne
